title: 114_s3449
content: The Act may be cited as the "Terrorism Art and Antiquity Revenue Prevention Act of 2016" or the "TAAR Act". It addresses stolen cultural property. Chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include provisions regarding the theft of cultural property valued at $50 or more. The term "cultural property" is defined in accordance with the Convention on Cultural Property Implementation Act. The amendment to Chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code includes provisions for the theft of cultural property valued at $50 or more. Cultural property removed or excavated in violation of local law is considered stolen. The term "cultural property" is defined in accordance with the Convention on Cultural Property Implementation Act. The term "veterans' memorial object" is defined as a grave marker, headstone, monument, or other object honoring a veteran. Cultural property removed in violation of local law is considered stolen for the purposes of an offense under this section. SEC. 3. Inventory database system for cultural property of Iraq or Syria legally entering the United States. The Secretary of Commerce, with the Under Secretary for Standards and Technology, will establish a scientific working group to identify data elements for characterizing cultural property from Iraq or Syria entering the US and evaluate labeling options. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with specified agencies and experts, will develop an inventory database system for cultural property. The agencies involved include the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury. The inventory database system for cultural property of Syria or Iraq in the United States will require importers or sellers to provide provenance information to the Secretary of Homeland Security, Department of Commerce, and other relevant federal agencies. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with other agencies, will develop regulations for dealers of cultural property to document and report transaction information. They will also work on creating a Federal database with provenance details and warnings for illegal trade in cultural property. The Secretary of Homeland Security will develop regulations for dealers to document and report transaction information and create a Federal database to combat illegal trade in cultural property. Cultural property is defined as per the Convention on Cultural Property Implementation Act.
